customData.content: Lumpectomy performed 2 days after memory problems were noticed.

HPI.summary: Memory problems noticed 2 days prior to lumpectomy

customData.content: Pathology report revealed infiltrative breast carcinoma of mixed type (80% non-specific, 20% lobular), histoprognostic grade I (2-2-1), histological tumour size of 30 mm along the long axis, lymphocytic stromal infiltrate estimated at 10%, without endovascular carcinomatous emboli and no involvement of perineural sheaths. Pathology report revealed ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate grade, cribriform type, representing 10% of the total tumour surface. Immunohistochemistry showed oestrogen receptors (95%), progesterone receptors (80%), proliferation index (10%), and no HER2 overexpression (score 0). Right axillary sentinel lymph nodes showed no metastasis (0/5).
Diagnosis of anti-LGI1 limbic encephalitis associated with early-stage breast cancer. MRI, EEG and positive anti-LGI1 antibodies supported the diagnosis of anti-LGI1 AE.
Resection of breast tumour with immunohistopathological analysis. Pathological stage (UICC, eighth edition 2017) was determined as pT2 N0 (sn) G1 R.
Immunosuppressive treatment was started within 24 hours of admission.
PNS care score: clinical level: 3 points, laboratory: 0, tumour level: not consistent with antibody, 1 point, total score of 4, indicating a possible PNS.

Patient recovered gradually, with no recurrence of headaches or focal epileptic seizures since hospitalisation. Partial retrograde and anterograde amnesia persisted during the initial week, followed by a slow and steady improvement.

HPI.summary: Patient recovered gradually with no recurrence of headaches or focal epileptic seizures since hospitalization.

customData.content: Patient returned to work with 80% of her previous time work 12 months after being discharged.

Neuropsychological evaluation at baseline showed impairment in verbal episodic memory (Free and Cued Selective Reminding Test) and visual episodic memory (recall of the Rey–Osterrieth complex figure). After 6 months of treatment, objective cognitive improvement was observed.

Whole-body FDG-18 PET scan revealed a moderately hypermetabolic lesion in the right breast. Breast biopsy revealed non-specific (ductal) infiltrative breast carcinoma, histoprognostic grade (SBRm/Nottingham) grade II (3-2-1), without ductal carcinoma in situ. Immunohistochemistry showed oestrogen receptors (100%) and progesterone receptors (80%). The proliferation index was at 10%, and there was a low immunohistochemical overexpression of HER2 (score 1+). Patient relies heavily on family to validate memories, constantly questioning the accuracy of recollections. Sleep disturbances and a consistent weight loss of approximately one kilogram per week. Patient experiencing pervasive fatigue

data.content: Patient developed memory problems following COVID-19 infection, leading to lumpectomy 2 days later.

Lumpectomy revealed infiltrative breast carcinoma of mixed type (80% non-specific, 20% lobular), histoprognostic grade I (2-2-1), histological tumour size of 30 mm along the long axis, lymphocytic stromal infiltrate estimated at 10%, without endovascular carcinomatous emboli and no involvement of perineural sheaths. Pathology report revealed ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate grade, cribriform type, representing 10% of the total tumour surface. Immunohistochemistry showed oestrogen receptors (95%), progesterone receptors (80%), proliferation index (10%), and no HER2 overexpression (score 0). Right axillary sentinel lymph nodes showed no metastasis (0/5).

Based on pathology report and memory problems, patient was diagnosed with anti-LGI1 limbic encephalitis associated with early-stage breast cancer. MRI, EEG and positive anti-LGI1 antibodies supported the diagnosis of anti-LGI1 AE.
PET scan was performed to further investigate the breast cancer diagnosis.
PET scan identified breast tumour, leading to resection of breast tumour with immunohistopathological analysis. Pathological stage (UICC, eighth edition 2017) was determined as pT2 N0 (sn) G1 R.
Following resection, immunosuppressive treatment was started within 24 hours of admission.
PNS care score was calculated, indicating a possible PNS.

Patient recovered gradually, with no recurrence of headaches or focal epileptic seizures since hospitalisation. Partial retrograde and anterograde amnesia persisted during the initial week, followed by a slow and steady improvement.
Patient's condition improved to the point where she returned to work with 80% of her previous time work 12 months after being discharged.

Neuropsychological evaluation at baseline showed impairment in verbal episodic memory (Free and Cued Selective Reminding Test) and visual episodic memory (recall of the Rey–Osterrieth complex figure). After 6 months of treatment, objective cognitive improvement was observed.

Whole-body FDG-18 PET scan revealed a moderately hypermetabolic lesion in the right breast. Breast biopsy revealed non-specific (ductal) infiltrative breast carcinoma, histoprognostic grade (SBRm/Nottingham) grade II (3-2-1), without ductal carcinoma in situ.
